45196: Staunch Defenders.author: wideyes
45196: Staunch Defenders.text_parsed: This card has been pretty useful for me in casual. It's not mythically awesome, but consider: it's a Sacred Nectar attached to a 3/4 vanilla. Not bad for 5CMC. Your opponent will think twice before bouncing it. If you have a way to get it back into your hand, you can up the lifegain. I have this in a deck with Narrow Escape, and they combo quite nicely - if it dies from combat or is removed, bounce it for 4 lifegain, cast it next turn for another 4 lifegain. That's 12 lifegain, which could easily extend your game by 1-2 turns. I like this guy.

45202: Circle of Protection: White.author: BegleOne
45202: Circle of Protection: White.text_parsed:
Cloudchaser Kestrel and Aurora Griffin can also be used with this card, but to get most affect out of them you're going to want to run a mono-white manabase, and in that case you'd be better off running Rune of Protection: White.

So Eight-and-a-Half-Tails is definitely the card you're looking for to combo with COP: W. Although Painter's Servant combos with any of the COP's, you're better off either picking red or black for all the natural hate available to white or blue for use with Llawan, Cephalid Empress.

45208: Intrepid Hero.author: 4wallz
45208: Intrepid Hero.text_parsed:
I remember I was playing a game where this was my last creature on the battlefield. My opponent had Silvos, Rogue Elemental out. I'm @ 6 life. I realize I'm about to loose. But then I remember a very nice rule. When a creature regenerates it taps.
So every time it is his turn I tap this guy to kill his Silvos. He regens him but it doesn't matter because he has to tap & can't attack with him. Needless to say he was mad. But this guy is was my MVP! Go old school!
45208: Intrepid Hero.text_posted:
I remember I was playing a game where this was my last creature on the battlefield.  My opponent had Silvos, Rogue Elemental out.  I'm @ 6 life.  I realize I'm about to loose.  But then I remember a very nice rule.  When a creature regenerates it taps.  
So every time it is his turn I tap this guy to kill his Silvos.  He regens him but it doesn't matter because he has to tap & can't attack with him.  Needless to say he was mad.  But this guy is was my MVP! Go old school!

45208: Intrepid Hero.author: BegleOne
45208: Intrepid Hero.text_parsed:
Gigantomancer only works on your own creatures, unfortunately, so you couldn't pump your opponent's and then kill them. Although if you have a Gigantomancer you usually just pump everything you have and swing hard.


I like running this guy in nice simple synergy with Giant Growth-type affects. Take their big stuff and kill it, turn the little stuff into big stuff and kill it, turn the Hero big when somebody else tries to kill it.

There isn't much funner in the game than taking out four or five consecutive Eldrazi with one card.

@Gabriel422

Nha, I don't see him as "Hollywood hero", only a Hero.

Heroes are suppose to defy all logic or statistics to beat a bigger opponent or archive a impossible goal, is because THEY ARE HEROES, they are persons that can overcome great difficulties to win! Heroes give us hope, because they defy the word "impossible". That why they are heroes: Because they do what seems IMPOSSIBLE to normal people, who hero don't do that?

A Firefighter that enters in a building in flames to save ONE person, despise all people saying that is impossible, is a hero. See? Heroes struggle against the impossible. It’s what a hero does. xD

45216: Blessed Reversal.author: martianshark
45216: Blessed Reversal.text_parsed:
Just started playing magic a few weeks ago. I first bought a Fiery Dawns starter pack, and bought a few cards (including this one) online. Then I battled someone for the first time, my friend with lots of powerful decks. After battling for a while, my friend decided to attack me with several different creatures. I played this and it saved me. If I didn't have this card, I would have lost then.

I ended up losing anyway, but I think this card has potential. It's super cheap to buy, and mana cost is pretty low too. If you are attacked by multiple creatures, this can be pretty useful. This is especially effective when your opponent has made lots of token creatures.

45216: Blessed Reversal.author: RiftenBlack
45216: Blessed Reversal.text_parsed:
This card is not befitting of a rare. It's a bad card. This card will not always be useful. When it is, it may very well just act as a fog, in which case, other fog type effects in later sets are better. When it is good and you actually gain life when the attack is over, it still doesn't help you answer the problem you've got - creatures are still attacking you. Card is just bad.

Your deck should not be designed to require this card to not die. If you rely on a card like this, you're deck is designed wrong.

45217: Rolling Stones.author: asaffin
45217: Rolling Stones.text_parsed:
@ MidgetfaceKillah: The band Iron Maiden took its name from the object that the card Iron Maiden represents; the card was not named after the band. This card, on the other hand... probably was.

When they introduced the Defender mechanic, they retroactively applied it to all Walls. However, cards like this that refer to walls in this or a similar capacity were not upgraded to represent the change. This is not fair. There are very few Wall creatures produced anymore, so this card is dead in any relatively modernized deck. A card game should not render any of its cards dead for any reason.
45217: Rolling Stones.text_posted:

45217: Rolling Stones.author: tavaritz
45217: Rolling Stones.text_parsed:
For those who lament why doesn't this affect non-wall defenders:

Conceptually walls are immobile structures where as non-wall defenders are home guard. So you need magic to get walls to attack, but you need a order from superiors to get a home guard to attack.

And to ajpinto: Read the Oracled text.

45224: Noble Purpose.author: sarroth
45224: Noble Purpose.text_parsed:
Murdershot21: "True Conviction" &
dragonking987: "murdershot21 wile (sic) True Conviction is better this dose (sic) have a few things over it like this stacks with lifelink and True Conviction dose (sic) not."

This is why I hate one-word comments on Gatherer. Is murdershot21 saying that True Conviction is better, or is he/she saying to run this with True Conviction? Or that the latter is a functional reprint? (this would be incorrect, but still a possible meaning to the post). You can't really tell with just one word or card name. Plus just saying that one thing doesn't really contribute anything of value.

The two cards are, however, fantastic together. Yes, any lifelink ability will be good with this since this isn't lifelink so they "stack," but True Conviction in particular is great because both have all of your creatures gaining a ton of life, instead of just the ones printed with lifelink or with auras/equipment that grant it. Plus True Conviction's double strike is insane with lifelink and Noble Purpose's life gain ability,

45227: Storm Crow.author: DeviousPie
45227: Storm Crow.text_parsed:
People should remember Storm Crow's secret abilities:
1) Shroud -- Opponents are too struck by awe to cast a spell on the majestic Storm Crow; Storm Crow has no flaws, so there is no point for you to cast a spell on it.
2) Fear -- Only creatures without hearts or minds can withstand Storm Crow's presence.
3) When Storm Crow deals damage to a player, that player loses the game -- Any player would naturally forfeit the after getting hit by Storm Crow once, for he cannot bear to suffer his wrath again. Surrender is the only sane option.

45233: Coastal Hornclaw.author: Henrietta
45233: Coastal Hornclaw.text_parsed: Aven Windreader and Hydromorph Gull are both almost strictly better, the only thing keeping them from being strictly better is that they have a cost of 3UU instead of 4U. There are numerous cards at a cost of 4U that are also almost strictly better, with the only difference being creature type (which TECHNICALLY prevents a creature from being strictly better than another, even if it doesn't actually happen in games with obscure creature types like Bird). There are also some cards at 2UU which are almost strictly better, with the differences being the creature type and amount of coloured mana in the cost. All in all, a completely outclassed card that's only saved from being strictly worse than many other cards by technicalities.
45233: Coastal Hornclaw.text_posted: [autocard]Aven Windreader[/autocard] and [autocard]Hydromorph Gull[/autocard] are both almost strictly better, the only thing keeping them from being strictly better is that they have a cost of 3UU instead of 4U. There are numerous cards at a cost of 4U that are also almost strictly better, with the only difference being creature type (which TECHNICALLY prevents a creature from being strictly better than another, even if it doesn't actually happen in games with obscure creature types like Bird). There are also some cards at 2UU which are almost strictly better, with the differences being the creature type and amount of coloured mana in the cost. All in all, a completely outclassed card that's only saved from being strictly worse than many other cards by technicalities.

45235: Twiddle.author: kitsunewarlock
45235: Twiddle.text_parsed:
A classic. It protects you from damage, gives you a blocker, lets you use that creature's tap ability twice, ramps your mana with cards like Tolarian Academy, Sol Ring or just Tron. It protects you from counter-spells by tapping out your opponent's last island, you can put it on Scepter to get an Icy Manipulator on crack. It lets you use your artifact again and de-activates artifacts like Winter Orb or Howling Mine. There have been many variations of this card, many of which are a tad stronger. But Twiddle will always maintain its status as the first.

This is probably the worst of the three art pieces for this card. Doesn't make much sense either...changing night to day is an untap/tap action? Guays and the original art were so beautiful though that its hard to compete.

45237: Invisibility.author: HuntingDrake
45237: Invisibility.text_parsed:
The strictly better Cloak of Mists was available to the Eighth Edition team, but they chose this instead.

One reason is that Eighth Edition included new reprints from every set.

Another is to support the Wall subtheme for Limited play: There were 8 walls (2 common, 5 uncommon, 1 rare), and 3 cards that cared about them (this, Dwarven Demolition Team, and Rolling Stones).

Aside: The number of cards that are Walls or care about Walls from Alpha through Magic 2011:
20, 19, 24, 22, 12, 10, 11, 0, 7, 4, 3 (plus M11 has 2 non-Wall defenders)

45241: Remove Soul.author: AdOutAce
45241: Remove Soul.text_parsed:
Not the flashiest, not the most flexible, but completely and utterly elegant. My favorite counterspell, and I'll tell you why.

When I was just a youngster, playing with a five-color monstrosity of randomly assembled cards from Invasion booster packs against other similar monstrosities, I happened upon Counterspell for the first time. Still having only learned the rules secondhand, this strange new type of spell fascinated me. I assumed it did exactly what it did, and asked around to confirm its function.

When I finally got the opportunity to try out my new weapon, the open-handed swatting-down of a Metamorphic Wurn, my friends were incredulous. That's too powerful they said, it couldn't be right. Creatures aren't spells anyway. They decided that spells are only instants, sorceries, an enchantments, obviously (the ones that sound like spells, I guess). I was disallowed from countering all manner of overcosted common fattiest that day.

But when I found this card, a fifth edition version that I bought in one of those repurposed packs of random cards from all sorts of old sets, I knew I had been right all along. It was a formative moment in Magic for me, where I started to think about the game as an accordance of rules with checks and balances. Not everything made common sense: creatures could be counterspelled, damage healed after every turn, and things coudn't block as many creatures as they wanted just because they were huge.

After that, I was hooked for good. And for that, I thank Remove Soul.

5/5
45241: Remove Soul.text_posted:
Not the flashiest, not the most flexible, but completely and utterly elegant. My favorite counterspell, and I'll tell you why.

When I was just a youngster, playing with a five-color monstrosity of randomly assembled cards from Invasion booster packs against other similar monstrosities, I happened upon [autocard]Counterspell[/autocard] for the first time. Still having only learned the rules secondhand, this strange new type of spell fascinated me. I assumed it did exactly what it did, and asked around to confirm its function.

When I finally got the opportunity to try out my new weapon, the open-handed swatting-down of a [autocard]Metamorphic Wurn[/autocard], my friends were incredulous. That's too powerful they said, it couldn't be right. Creatures aren't spells anyway. They decided that spells are only instants, sorceries, an enchantments, obviously (the ones that sound like spells, I guess). I was disallowed from countering all manner of overcosted common fattiest that day.

But when I found this card, a fifth edition version that I bought in one of those repurposed packs of random cards from all sorts of old sets, I knew I had been right all along. It was a formative moment in Magic for me, where I started to think about the game as an accordance of rules with checks and balances. Not everything made common sense: creatures could be counterspelled, damage healed after every turn, and things coudn't block as many creatures as they wanted just because they were huge.

After that, I was hooked for good. And for that, I thank Remove Soul.

5/5

45253: Fighting Drake.author: Soul__Power
45253: Fighting Drake.text_parsed:
Why is Water Servant better than this card? So many reasons...

First, it is totally fair to compare this to Water Servant because both cards are 4 cmc blue creatures. I don't know what kind of decks you're making, but a 4 cmc blue creature is no more than a single niche in any of my decks (meaning I will only ever have one of these two creatures, never both in my decks).

Second, if a creature has evasion you want it's big stat to be its power, not its toughness. If this guy was a 4/2 flier he would actually be decent competition for Water Servant, but he's not and he isn't.

Third, this creature is far more vulnerable to cards like Lightning Bolt and Mizzium Mortars. Water Servant has something called versatility which means he can be good against more than one deck archetype while this creature only really takes advantage of decks running a lot of evasion.

45257: Shifting Sky.author: Muddybuddy

Is that in addition to their current color?  DCI ruling please...
45257: Shifting Sky.text_posted: Does this card remove colors already assigned to cards? It doesn't say that it does, it doesn't say it replaces them or makes them x color instead of their current colors.  It just says that they are now x color. 45257: Shifting Sky.author: zandergb
45257: Shifting Sky.text_parsed:
@Muddybuddy
Unless a card says "in addition to", the replacement color/subtype/whatever gets rid of the previous color/subtype/whatever.
45257: Shifting Sky.text_posted:
@Muddybuddy
Unless a card says "in addition to", the replacement color/subtype/whatever gets rid of the previous color/subtype/whatever.

45258: Intruder Alarm.author: nimzo
45258: Intruder Alarm.text_parsed:
My old Intruder Alarm deck ("standard" in Odyssey & Onslaught block and 8th Edition) was built around him, with the other center piece Words of Wind and Cryptic Gateway (yes Ohms89, I agree!) . Other cards was: Basking Rootwalla, a totally free spell, Llanowar Elves, Aphetto Alchemist, Krosan Restorer, Elvish Aberration for some mana producing, Merfolk Looter, Arcanis the Omnipotent, Careful Study, Standstill for drawing/discarding card (discarding the free Rootwalla, of course), the solid Genesis, and the very useful Anger (I don't forgot some Mountain in this green-blue deck!) to give haste at everybody.

Not a competitive deck, but a funny one with friends... Intruder Alarm is one of my favorite non-broken combo card ever, and I think is complicate for Wizard to reprint it in Core set...

45261: Aven Fisher.author: ClockworkSwordfish
45261: Aven Fisher.text_parsed:
This card may appear bad, but it actually saved my ass once.

I was playing with my family and my dad had an Omnath, Locus of Mana combo on the field (Patron of the Orochi and Awakening), so he had a stupid amount of mana.

Then he played Soul's Fire on Omnath and pointed it at my mom.

Since my mom had helped me earlier, I had made a truce with her and, as part of the deal, , I had to try to protect her

I also knew that she had a hand full of burn and, if I couldn't save her, might send it at me, and I was only at 5.

My dad was at 19, so I knew it was pretty unlikely she'd be able to kill him with whatever burn she had, but she could probably kill me.

I had an Urza's Armor, but of course that wouldn't really stop anywhere near enough of the 50+ damage coming at me.

So, hoping to flip over some kind of counterspell, I played, appropriately enough, a Frantic Search and flipped this over. Then my mom got scared and said 'You're movin' with your auntie and uncle in Bel Air'

I begged and pleaded with her day after day
But she packed my suitcase and send me on my way
She gave me a kiss and then she gave me my ticket.
I put my walkman on and said, 'I might as well kick it'.

First class, yo this is bad
Drinking orange juice out of a champagne glass.
Is this what the people of Bel-Air Living like?
Hmmmmm this might be alright.

But wait I hear there're prissy, bourgeois and all that
Is this the type of place that they should send this cool cat?
I don't think so
I'll see when I get there
I hope they're prepared for the prince of Bel-Air

Well, the plane landed and when I came out
There was a dude who looked like a cop standing there with my name out
I ain't trying to get arrested yet
I just got here
I sprang with the quickness like lightning, disappeared

I whistled for a cab and when it came near
The license plate said fresh and it had dice in the mirror
If anything I can say that this cab was rare
But I thought 'Nah forget it' - 'Yo homes to Bel Air'

I pulled up to the house about 7 or 8
And I yelled to the cabbie 'Yo homes smell ya later'
I looked at my kingdom
I was finally there
To sit on my throne as the Prince of Bel Air

45262: Concentrate.author: BongRipper420
45262: Concentrate.text_parsed:
Even though they're functionally equal, I find Harmonize much more effective and practical. Simply because 4 mana is nothing for Green, while Blue won't be able to do much else the turn it uses this card. Which in my eyes makes this seem less playable than it's green counterpart. Though this card is still fantastic.

In my opinion, Green draw power in general is on par with, if not better than Blue's draw power options as of late, and can more easily refill it's hand completely. Not that blue is at all unable to do so, but with cards like Glimpse of Nature, Collective Unconscious, Hunter's Insight, Fecundity, Regal Force, Garruk, Primal Hunter, Momentous Fall, Soul's Majesty, Primordial Sage, Greater Good, Citanul Woodreaders, ect. It's hard to deny that Green is at least able to compete with Blue in the department of draw power.

Still, this card desrves a solid 4/5 in my opinion. It's all sorts of awesome.

45263: Steal Artifact.author: creedfox
45263: Steal Artifact.text_parsed: so, if i use this on an equipment already attached to a creature and gain control of equipment, does the equipment become unequipped when i gain control of it? because i have an enchantment that says enchant creature and opponent controls and if i gain control of the creature it is unattached due to a state based effect. since equip ability says equip to target creature you control does it work the same way?
45263: Steal Artifact.text_posted: so, if i use this on an equipment already attached to a creature and gain control of equipment, does the equipment become unequipped when i gain control of it? because i have an enchantment that says enchant creature and opponent controls and if i gain control of the creature it is unattached due to a state based effect. since equip ability says equip to target creature you control does it work the same way?

45263: Steal Artifact.author: Etsap
45263: Steal Artifact.text_parsed:
@creedfox

No, the equipment does not become unequipped. Equipment can be attached to creatures that are controlled by another player with cards like Vulshok Battlemaster. The actual Equip ability can only target a creature you control, but once attached it doesn't care who controls what any more.

The important thing to note is that if you control the equipment, then you can pay the equip cost and move it to one of your creatures. The person who controls the equipped creature can no longer pay the equip cost of the equipment, nor any other abilities of the equipment (such as Sunforger or Sword of the Paruns). Equipment that grants abilities to the creature (such as Viridian Longbow) are still only able to be activated by the controller of the creature, so read carefully!

Force of Will requires discarding it and another card, and it's still the most essential counterspell ever. This you have to have 4 mana out to play, meaning that your opponent knows you could counter, and that it can't be played as early. The only advantage of this is the ability to play another instant after it, which isn't completely worth it for twice the cost of counterspell.

45268: Archivist.author: blurrymadness
45268: Archivist.text_parsed:
I say "meh." Even replacing this with a simple "Draw 3" spell seems preferable. It's not the worst, but I gave it a low rating for the sheer slowness of it. Were it a 1/3 I might be more forgiving, but it dies to *every* form of removal, including single pingers, Riot Spikes, and similar. Compared to something like Azami, we see that it takes very little mana to get a huge difference in effectiveness.

Something like Fallowsage is also a good example. It can attack or utilize other tap abilities to draw the cards while being out of range for the lower removal/ping types. I don't know, this just seems bad to me.

45275: Merchant Scroll.author: nope.avi
45275: Merchant Scroll.text_parsed:
Very much a card for a combo deck. It lets one search for their combo pieces, or for protection for it. It could be used in a control deck, however in those it's just for the most part a worse brainstorm, or a ponder, or a worse mystical teachings. However in a combo deck it's amazing, it lets one search for things such as pact of negation, for those hive mind decks, or for high tide, or meditate or w/e. Again in a straight up control deck it's terrible, for that matter most tutors are pretty bad in control decks, unless you're running a tutor board, where one sides in a thing such as enlightened tutor and other random hosers.

But searching for burn with this is terrible, yay you're paying 5 mana to do 2 damage and draw a card, seems good, burn is only good when it's efficient, and having to tutor for it to use it is terrible.
45275: Merchant Scroll.text_posted:
Very much a card for a combo deck. It lets one search for their combo pieces, or for protection for it. It could be used in a control deck, however in those it's just for the most part a worse brainstorm, or a ponder, or a worse mystical teachings. However in a combo deck it's amazing, it lets one search for things such as pact of negation, for those hive mind decks, or for high tide, or [autocard]meditate[/autocard] or w/e. Again in a straight up control deck it's terrible, for that matter most tutors are pretty bad in control decks, unless you're running a tutor board, where one sides in a thing such as enlightened tutor and other random hosers.

But searching for burn with this is terrible, yay you're paying 5 mana to do 2 damage and draw a card, seems good, burn is only good when it's efficient, and having to tutor for it to use it is terrible.

45276: Balance of Power.author: sarroth
45276: Balance of Power.text_parsed: This card really should be white. White is lacking in a distinctive form of card draw other than enchantresses, and not all white decks want to run that many enchantments. But balancing, which is even in the name, is very white, such as with, say, Balance. This card still wouldn't be amazing if it was white, but I bet it would be appreciated in white, especially in EDH/Commander, as the white mage otherwise has access to less good card draw options than the blue mage does. At least a 3/5 if it were white, but as it is blue and it has to fight a lot more cards for the slot, a 2/5 only because of the interesting design (1/5 on power level alone).

45306: Carrion Wall.author: DoctorKenneth
45306: Carrion Wall.text_parsed:
The problem isn't that it's a bad card. It's not, really. It's not even so much that you can probably get a decent regenrating non-wall creature for three mana in black (Sanguine Guard, for example, trading +1/+0 for First strike and the ability to actually attack, which I hear is useful). It's that what you want from a wall is survivability, not power. This wall has regeneration going for it. But generally, if this thing can't attack, you want to hope that it can soak up some damage, and do it for cheap. You need to leave two mana open for this guy to do what it's meant to do. And since nearly any enemy creature can break apart your wall with ease, you need to make sure those open lands never do tap if you value your investment.

This is probably why walls that act more like walls have been favoured for modern reprinting. Compare Wall of Bone. It's clearly easier to leave the one mana open than two, and during the early game, you can even tap out without fear- the 4-toughness wall can block the average one-to-four drop all day long, and eat attacking weenies. Sure, it can't kill bigger creatures. That's not the point of a wall. Leave the killing for your non-walls- anything with Defender is at it's most useful when it can, indeed, defend.

It's a pretty big nerf over Hypnotic Specter. One mana make a huge difference with discard, because you need to start making your opponent discard as fast as possible, before they have a chance to bring out their key cards; and the difference between a random discard and a chosen discard is also huge.

But it's still a very good and usable card, which just shows how overpowered Hypnotic Specter was.

If this card were to be named like most other cards it would be something like "Ambition's Reward".

45317: Sever Soul.author: Villainous1
45317: Sever Soul.text_parsed:
Are you kids crazy?? If this thing was any cheaper or better it would be brokenly powerful!

Compare with Dark Banishing. For two more mana (and based on the kind of things you should be using this on) you could be getting anywhere from 3-8 life or more. Plus if your opponent knows you have it somewhere in your deck they'll be scared to drop their big beasties until it's taken care of - the kind of beasties they'd be dropping around oh, I don't know, turn 5 maybe? Plus as a sorcery you won't be paranoid about saving enough mana to use it whenever, unlike an instant...

Overall, a very underrated card.

45317: Sever Soul.author: Henrietta
45317: Sever Soul.text_parsed: No, this card is just bad, and it wouldn't be broken even if it cost 2B. Why would any competitive player ever use this over, say, Doom Blade? The non-regeneration clause is highly situational, sorcery speed is in fact a disadvantage and not an advantage like you seem to think, and life gain alone is not worth an extra three mana, even if you do gain 6+ life off of it. This card would be a fine casual card at 2BB, instant speed, destroy any creature, but as it is it's not even worth running in casual.

45324: Lord of the Undead.author: Silverware
45324: Lord of the Undead.text_parsed:
While I would hesitate to say this card is better than Zombie Master since this card does not give your creatures any form of evasion and can bring your creatures back to your hand not stop them from dying altogther, I would still consider this card on par with Zombie Master, really they are two lords with two very diffrent uses.

Lord of the Undead is one of my personal favorite lords. A major contester for your 3 drops in any zombie deck.

I personaly run 4 of these in my mono-black zombie deck and really they are a must to keep your zombies from staying locked away in the graveyard. Also brining back a nameless inversion or a fleshbag marauder every turn can be pretty game changing as it often allows you to shut down your opponents creature generation altogther.

Also if you need more ways to bring back your zombies to put presure on the field consider unearth and unholy grotto.

45326: Western Paladin.author: Raexs
45326: Western Paladin.text_parsed:
I don't like the 8th Edition crossover of flavor text and art of the two previous versions. Separately, the two previous incarnations were very different flavor-wise - but both very cool in their own way.
This artwork does not portray the power-hungry backstabber as the flavor text describes, like the 7th Edition one was. He looks like a cold-blooded Phyrexian killing machine like the Urza's Saga one was.
They should have just given him new flavor text, considering the Northern Paladin wasn't even in 8th Edition, and mention of Yawgmoth in a core set may be seen as uncouth.

45329: Death Pits of Rath.author: jeff-heikkinen
45329: Death Pits of Rath.text_parsed: I don't know multiplayer, but this looks like a waste in any form of two-player Constructed. Hopefully most things you damage in that environment die anyway, so including an expensive and invested card just to make sure of this is of extremely limited use. In Limited, on the other hand, this is an excellent way to stall the ground - you should be very hesitant to attack an opponent with Death Pits if there's any possibility of being blocked, since it enables some extremely unbalanced trades. Of course, in theory this effect is symmetrical - but in practise, the person playing Death Pits knew he was doing so and had a chance to build a deck to take advantage of it, and the other guy didn't. Especially powerful in Limited with something like Prodigal Sorcerer, of course.

45332: Larceny.author: PhyrexianLobbiest
45332: Larceny.text_parsed:
I run this, and you're right it is slow, but it's a great augmentation. Let's say you have two Megrim's in play and you attack with Hypnotic Specter. The opponent has to take it to the face because they don't have flying. The opponent takes 2 to the face from the Specter, and have to toss a card due to its ability. This triggers the two Megrims for 2 damage apiece; for a total of 6 damage.

Reply that same scenario with Larceny on deck as well; now when the Specter attacks it does 2 to the opponent itself, trigger its own ability AND Larceny which results in the opponent having to discard 2 cards; which triggers both Megrim's twice. Larceny ups the damage from 6 to 10, and further locks down the opponent by causing them to loose the second card.

It's a great augmentation in a Blue Black deck where you've got enough counters to protect your enchantments.

45335: Murderous Betrayal.author: Aquillion
45335: Murderous Betrayal.text_parsed:
Utterly worthless. To even beat a Terror you have to use it twice and pay 3/4ths of your life, at which point you've also spent 9 mana. There are better things to spend that on.

If you want to spend life in exchange for anti-creature card advantage, just run Ashes to Ashes instead. Yes, this can be used at less life, but Ashes to Ashes eliminates creatures much faster, which is worth far far more; and can be used better in the early game anyway, which is when it really counts. Plus, it exiles.

Also, regarding all those people saying that there's no way to make your opponent suffer the life loss: Mirror Universe! There are much better ways to lower your life for that, though. Try Lich.

45335: Murderous Betrayal.author: Leo...Preliator
45335: Murderous Betrayal.text_parsed:
118.4 If a cost or effect allows a player to pay an amount of life greater than 0, the player may do so only if his or her life total is greater than or equal to the amount of the payment.

Everyone saying Lich and platinum angel combos isn't right. You can't pay life you don't have, so if your life is at 0 or lower, you can't pay any life, so you can't activate the card.
45335: Murderous Betrayal.text_posted:
118.4 If a cost or effect allows a player to pay an amount of life greater than 0, the player may do so only if his or her life total is greater than or equal to the amount of the payment.

45335: Murderous Betrayal.author: Smokingpapyrus
45335: Murderous Betrayal.text_parsed:
@Leo...Preliator

At 0 life you would have to pay 0 life, so that doesn't pose a problem. I'm not 100% how this is handled in MTG but half of a negative number is a negative number. So mathematically if you were at -4 you would lose -2 life (aka you would gain 2 life).

Looked it up and apparently when a negative life total is used for calculations it is treated as zero. So anything under 0 makes you lose 0 life, a cost you can always pay.

It works.
45335: Murderous Betrayal.text_posted:

45336: Grave Pact.author: Misago
45336: Grave Pact.text_parsed: (Card Rating: 4.0) Grave Pact is always a pleasure to play in a multiplayer format. If your oponent's do not have an answer for an enchantment in thier hand, any strategy they have involving even the most sturdy of creatures (i.e. Progenitus) will be fruitless. In light of the hefty 3 black mana required to cast it, Grave Pact is a rather difficult card to splash. Because having more than one in your hand equates to a dead card, Grave Pact makes my list of superb "one of's". Since you will be already running black, I recommend Demonic Tutor and Vampiric Tutor to make it seem like you are running three in your deck. If you are on a budget, Diabolic Tutor will suffice. In my favorite casual black/red goblin deck, I run 1 Grave Pact along with... 4 Mogg War Marshal, 2 Goblin Chirurgeon, 2 Skirk Prospector, and 1 Tuktuk the Explorer to ensure fodder plus an instance speed FREE sac. engine. I also run 1 Goblin Warrens to 99% ensure an opponent will NOT have a creature on the board! A Phyrexian Tower also works well to supply the sacrifice engine and black mana needed. On a side note, the artwork for the 8th edition version is fantastic. Check it out! (Posted By: Misago)

45336: Grave Pact.author: MisterAction
45336: Grave Pact.text_parsed:
This is my favorite art for this card, and I feel those who say it doesn't make sense are misinterpreting it.

The grim reaper's job is to take dead souls to the afterlife, not put bodies in graves. That's why the grave is filled in.

This is what happens when Death comes to take you, and you argue with him that you're not dead. He takes you to your own grave and points to it, as if to say "Oh yeah? Well tell me, wiseguy, if you're not dead, what's your body doing six feet below a tombstone?"
45336: Grave Pact.text_posted:
This is my favorite art for this card, and I feel those who say it doesn't make sense are misinterpreting it.

The grim reaper's job is to take dead souls to the afterlife, not put bodies in graves.  That's why the grave is filled in.

This is what happens when Death comes to take you, and you argue with him that you're not dead.  He takes you to your own grave and points to it, as if to say "Oh yeah?  Well tell me, wiseguy, if you're not dead, what's your body doing six feet below a tombstone?"

45338: Death Pit Offering.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
45338: Death Pit Offering.text_parsed:
I really like this card - that is a substantial boost for your creatures, and the drawback on the card is one that is most easily overcome by anyway.

What it does do, though, is paint a big target on your forehead. Obviously in a duel it doesn't make much of a difference, but when you play this in a multiplayer scenario, expect a lot of aggression to suddenly come your way - nobody else will want to see you start to benefit from this! Deadpool's second suggestion above, about accelerating it out quickly, is the best way to play this card, because it'll minimize the pain that will come your way.

Another thought - pair it with another staple black enchantment, Grave Pact! People will still want to hurt you, but they should have far fewer creatures to do it with in the turn following Death Pits.

45341: Cinder Wall.author: Lateralis0ne
45341: Cinder Wall.text_parsed:
@ Joker--

Because Cinder Wall is the only card being named in the text, it stands to reason that because it is the only named entity, it is the only entity affected by that ruling. If it explicitly affects the creature that is being blocked by the wall, then at the very least the Oracle wording would dictate as such, and would be written something like:

"Whenever Cinder Wall blocks an attacking creature, destroy that creature at end of combat." Here, 'that creature' refers to the attacking creature; named such as it's rather impractical to give 'that creature' a definitive name (Cinder Wall can block many creatures, not one specific creature).

Again, 'it' refers to the card that the text is on. As stated, it would be worded differently if 'it' meant any other card.
45341: Cinder Wall.text_posted:
@ Joker--

45361: Lightning Blast.author: OpenSeasonNoobs
45361: Lightning Blast.text_parsed: Don't compare this to Lightning Bolt, bolt is by far the best burn spell ever made if you're comparing mana to damage. However, this card is a LOT more valuable than most people think. It's Galvanic Blast but instead of having to have spent mana to bring out artifacts, it just costs more. You don't have to build a deck around it. And it does 4 damage, enough to kill a lot of the creatures you're going to be afraid of. Combine it with a lightning bolt and you spend 5 mana to get rid of a 7 toughness fatty. Sure, you can get rid of a 6 toughness fatty by using 2 bolts, but then you've only got 2 bolts possible left in your deck. It saves you from having to waste your better spells. 3.5/5, it's playable, but not a Legacy card.

45361: Lightning Blast.author: DarthParallax
45361: Lightning Blast.text_parsed:
OpenSeasonNoobs, your a Noob.

Im all for defending underdog cards and explaining why non-lightning bolt cards are still good, but you did the right thing for the wrong reasons. comparing this metalcrafting galvanic, you are paying a similar amount of mana without getting the extra benefit from Ornithopters, Memnites, Moxen, Lotus Petals, Sol Rings, ok some of those the average player might not have but my point is that Galvanic Blast requiring artifacts is NOT a draw back and with the right artifacts you make a deck that can race a mono red deck without artifacts.
further, when you talk about 'saving your good spells', you should build your deck so that all 60 of the cards in it are good. 4x Lightning Bolt, 4x Searing Blaze, 4x Slagstorm...first of all that makes your draws more consistent (high number of high quality cards) second, using the best quality spells you can means that each individual spell is costs less anxiety to play. it sounds like in your deck I would always be afraid to play Lightning Bolt because I wouldn't know when I was ever going to draw a good for the rest of the game, whereas my kind of list lets me play all 4 of my Bolts as Terminates instead of Axes and not worry about running out of steam because I know I'll have more goodies in the rest of my draw.

The REAL reason to play Lightning Blast, or Char, or Flame Javelin, is because no matter how mana efficient you think you're being, spending 2 cards to do something 1 can is just bad. I would never tack a Lava Dart on to a Lightning Bolt. I need BOTH of them if they're both in my deck, so I can have enough cards to ping enemy attackers and burn your life. If I start letting you 2-for-1 me just by playing 4-toughness creatures, or worse 2-toughness creatures that Tribal up to 5-or-more, then I will not have enough cards to kill you AND prevent you from killing me first, whereas you will have an unopposable army of permanents. that's not a good place to be. One way to build a red deck is to first guess 'how many creatures in the average deck Im likely to face?', then put in an equal number of red spells, looking to trade 1-for-1. Now add in enough cards to do 20 damage to the face. use as many 'creatures or players' and '2-for-1' cards as possible. So take your Chars and your Lightning Blasts along with your Bolts, and MAKE EVERY SPELL COUNT!

45361: Lightning Blast.author: leomistico
45361: Lightning Blast.text_parsed:
@ DarthParallax:
I like the way you think...!

A 4-damages spell is way more powerful than a 3-damages one, because you don't have to spend more than 1 card to deal with bigger thread!
However, DarthParallax, may I suggest you to include some Pyroclasm or equivalent spell, to burn 2 or 3 creatures at once, so you can save more spells to deal direct damages to the opponent? I think that this way it's a better deck. Then fill it with Char, Flame Javelin, Fireblast and other quality spell, as you like...

This card for me is perfect, because is balanced and simple, one of the card that could set the standard of the burn spells, something like a vanilla creature... Not every card have to be complex, and the simple version of some effect is always welcomed!

4/5

45373: Boil.author: jsttu
45373: Boil.text_parsed: Evil card. This card and others like it such as tsunami or flashfire should never have been made. They aren't good enough for tournaments but when successful they break the game to casual players with known decks. If a friend has a mono white deck it doesn't matter how good it is if they lose all their lands. The great thing about Magic: The Gathering is the almost unlimited possibilities and creativity available. This card limits that. There is a reason you do not see these effects anymore.

45373: Boil.author: divine_exodus
45373: Boil.text_parsed:
@Zoah:

As shadygrove said, them having to keep 4 mana open all the time is a huge disadvantage. If I see my opponent tapping mana for something, but they still have cards in their hand and untapped lands, I immediately think that they will cast an instant, and I should probably keep at least 3 mana open. Of course, sometimes you really need to cast a frost titan or Lorthos, in which case I make sure I have a creature that can counter or a force of will. As a blue player, I tend to tap out all my lands only under extreme circ-umstances or if I can counter without paying mana. This card may at first seem very deadly, but if you do run control blue, you should almost always be able to cast a counterspell.

45373: Boil.author: Zoah
45373: Boil.text_parsed:
Target blue player loses the game. That's it. The end!
I hate this card! There are other cards that say "Destroy all plains" or whatever, but they don't activate at the speed of an instant, and they cost the same as this one.

Edit: to address this more calmly (Being that everyone hates this comment) here is the advantage this card gives:
A, you can not tap out all your manna in this turn, because if you do they untap theirs.
B, you aren't allowed to play anything on their turn until they have less then four. So you can't counter anything else.
C. If you have only one counterspell left, you can't use it on anything else.
D. They can play it as early as turn four and it's a solid win condition. So even tapping out as early as turn three, could result in a rather sound defeat.
E. If they have a quick deck, and don't have much else to spend manna on, as is often the case with red, holding onto their manna might not be so hard.

Boiling Seas Now that's what the card should look like.

Magic R&D keeps a set of very generic unused artworks in case the artists screw up the art order and turn lemures into lemurs or a calendar into a colander.

45382: Okk.author: Psuedonaut
45382: Okk.text_parsed: Phyrexian Dreadnought. A 12/12 for 7.

45382: Okk.author: Mode
45382: Okk.text_parsed:
Cliffrunner Behemoth also seems like a decent choice with him.
Or some really bad guys like Abyssal Persecutor, Juzám Djinn or Grinning Demon. Green and black are besides red likely the best colors to find cheap "fight compagnons" to make this guy move a leg. Try a Phyrexian Negator xD
If he wasn't equally hard to cast in a non-monoblack deck, i'd think about using Phylactery Lich. Avatar of Discord on the other hand shouldn't be a problem in a red/black deck.

Strenchskipper, Boggart Mob and Goblin Goon would work in a goblin deck. (But in the case of the latter, you'd have to provide enough creatures to look for the goon again.)
There are even several one-drops that can help: Death's Shadow, Scute Mob and Dragonmaster Outcast.
Volcano Hellion would also synergize with the shadow.
Hunted Horror is also nice, since Okk can destroy one of the 3/3 centaur tokens, and disregarding other creatures your opponent will have to take seven damage from it if he wants to kill Okk with both centaurs.
If your opponent has creatures, Sheltering Ancient is pretty neat.
Tempting Wurm...still doesn't sound too tempting :D

Rumbling Slum or Spellbreaker Behemoth is certainly a good choice for green/red.
Balduvian Horde and Emperor Crocodile are two classics (aside from Juzám of course).
Gathan Raiders is a nice or even better alternate for Balduvian Horde.
(If you like coin flipping: Goblin Mutant, Fickle Efreet and Mijae Djinn are for you.)

Enchantments that cause cip-triggers based on the creature's power also synergize with him:
Pandemonium, Electropotence, Warstorm Surge can cause damage, and Kavu Lair lets you draw a card.

Nulltread Gargantuan is also blue, but too interesting not to mention.
Add Shivan Wumpus or Argothian Wurm and let them live happily together in the Kavu Lair.

Last but not least, good old Rancor can also help your smaller creatures to get stronger than Okk.

It just bugs me a little that Okks abilities are variable, and not specified to say "power 5 or greater", because in that case you could have two Okks fighting together with a little power boost.

45394: Inferno.author: sonorhC
45394: Inferno.text_parsed:
@deadeye1387, Whispersilk Cloak wouldn't interact with this at all, since this doesn't target. What you want is something that either gives a ton of toughness, like Slagwurm Armor, or prevents damage, like protection (say, from a Sword of Fire and Ice).

Oh, and it's really simple to tell if something targets (and thus is stopped by shroud): If it says the word "target" on the card, it targets. This doesn't.

This is disturbing. I agree with the Jaya Ballard Fan Club.....but I checked every edition. I don't really like any of the artworks.

We need to get rid of Chandra, bring back Jaya, and reprint this card with Jaya text and a Balefire Dragon :)

(I actually like Chandra- however, it seems that Red has a sadly very shallow Design space for Walkers, so one way to shake things up and be 'fresh'- one amazingly obvious epic way- is to simply bring back a well loved character and let the story-telling do the work of being cool. 45395: Thieves' Auction.author: Lancer873
45395: Thieves' Auction.text_parsed: I wish that this was a good shenanigans card, but as it is it ends up leaving you alone and vulnerable and everyone else with their picks of the best cards for a turn. Since it has to be on your turn (sorcery speed) and it ends with everything tapped, you have to survive a whole round with no defenses, and unless you really helped someone out by casting this then there's going to be someone who will attack you without anything getting in their way.

45405: Lone Wolf.author: jonrds
45405: Lone Wolf.text_parsed:
One of my all time favorite cards. When I was about 10, I was borrowing someone's deck (it was one of those 100 card casual decks that just have every green card the person owns) and playing a quick 5 health game against the best person in my friend group.

I chumpblock him, losing all but my lone wolf in the process, and he puts down another 8/8, giving him about 30 power on the board. I draw and play my 6th land, allowing me to play tribal unity, giving my wolf 3 more power. Swing for the win, your blockers can't help you now.

45411: Moss Monster.author: kitsunewarlock
45411: Moss Monster.text_parsed: Awful card and an example of why people hate 8th and 9th edition moreso than any other core sets (except, maybe, fifth for its large size and rarity upgrades to some cards as bad as this).  They take a useless older card and reprint it just to say they have.  Then they get rid of its only classic appeal--its art--and give it this.  This art is seriously bad.  It gives me no feeling of unsettling creepiness like the last one and at the same time doesn't set any sort of scene.  The creature typing on this stinks too.  Mossdog is a Plant--yet somehow Moss Monster is an elemental.  Not that plants are any kind of tribe--but it'd definately be a fun one if it was.  More fun than this guy, I'd imagine.

45412: Monstrous Growth.author: Lacunae
45412: Monstrous Growth.text_parsed:
I never much cared for the art of this card until, years after my first impression of it, I noticed the little druid in black in the lower right corner, with his sickle and glowing red eyes. Then I realized that the stones in the picture weren't just random rocks but a stonehenge style ritual circle.

Now the illustration has a connotation of ancient fertility ritual, The Great God Pan, the Black Goat of the Woods and all kinds of other sinister things that predate civilization and reason, and fit in very well with Green, but don't seem to have been explored too thoroughly. (Incidentally, I think they really missed out on an opportunity to give Green this flavor on Innistrad.)

Anyhow, if I can get one person to, like me, stop ignoring this art as incomprehensible filler and start appreciating it, writing all this was worth it.

And with that, I think I've spent more time thinking about this card than R&D did.
45412: Monstrous Growth.text_posted:

Now the illustration has a connotation of ancient fertility ritual, The Great God Pan, the Black Goat of the Woods and all kinds of other sinister things that predate civilization and reason, and fit in very well with Green, but don't seem to have been explored too thoroughly.  (Incidentally, I think they really missed out on an opportunity to give Green this flavor on Innistrad.)

Anyhow, if I can get one person to, like me, stop ignoring this art as incomprehensible filler and start appreciating it, writing all this was worth it.

And with that, I think I've spent more time thinking about this card than R&D did.

Especially with Chord of Calling you could do some wicked stuff, imagine playing a Mycoloth round three gobbling up all of the creatures => 14/14 Mycoloth giving birth to 10 Saprolings a round... all all because of this card :D

And you could do this with instant speed, so just use chord of calling Round 3 before you upkeep...

I like!

A must in any green-based multi-colored deck. Drop it on a forest with an Arbor Elf:

turn 2: mountain, Fertile Ground

45416: Fertile Ground.author: Ragamander
45416: Fertile Ground.text_parsed:
Utopia Sprawl does it better.

T1: Forest, Arbor Elf
T2: Forest, Utopia Sprawl, tap for , untap it, tap for again, Freed from the Real, untap Arbor Elf, infinite green mana, win somehow

With more expensive dual lands you can get infinite blue mana, and you can also use Pemmin's Aura. As it stands though, two Forests, Arbor Elf, Utopia Sprawl, Freed from the Real, and Goblin Cannon are all it takes to win the game turn 2, and you can build a combo-deck that does it fairly well for about $10.

45426: Hunted Wumpus.author: Kefra

Surprised no one else has mentioned the reference, so...

"Hunt the Wumpus" is an early computer game first released in text-based form in 1972. The first version with graphics debuted in 1980. The object of the game is, not surprisingly, to shoot the Wumpus as you chase it through a grid of rooms.

45432: Spreading Algae.author: GCNDAN3702
45432: Spreading Algae.text_parsed:
This is a card that looks better on paper then in practice. Any sensible opponent would never tap their enchanted swamp for mana, so you'll rarely see the second and third triggers go off.

Having said that, it does essentially deny the opponent an extra land (which is almost equivalent to destroy a land permanently), so for 1 green, that's some pretty good hate.

Of course, with some fun tapping shenanigans from say... Rishadan Port, this card can be everything you wanted it to be!

45432: Spreading Algae.author: blurrymadness
45432: Spreading Algae.text_parsed:
Want to find Urborg, Tomb?
Use living wish!

Want to find it in your deck?
Use knight of the reliquary!

Keeping one in your deck and one in sideboard means you can start the algae between T2 and T3 with minor acceleration. It only takes a tiny bit of land advantage before your opponent is locked out of the game

Who'd have thought that the easiest way to abuse black would be in it's enemies' colors, using green black-hate?

45439: Birds of Paradise.author: rubber
45439: Birds of Paradise.text_parsed: Everyone loves the Birds. They're wonderful mana boosting and a classic card. However, I can't understand why, at the time of this comment, 9 people have rated this card 5/5, and no one has gone any lower. It's a wonderful card, but come on. For most situations either Llanowar Elves or Noble Hierarch are significantly better. The only time a deck should use them is if it needs cmc1 mana boosting for black or red, or if it needs more than 4 cmc 1 boosters. Also, this is the version with relatively bland artwork. 4/5

45439: Birds of Paradise.author: Mode
45439: Birds of Paradise.text_parsed:
__ART RANT__

In my humble opinion, this artwork in the new frame is the prettiest and most fitting printing of this card so far.

The only thing that slightly bugs me is the white border, but even that fits pretty nicely in this case.
And you can even get this in black-bordered perfection if you manage to get your hands on a foil version of these.

As CollectiveC said, the iridescent interpretation from Ravnica that's been used in the past ten years is imposing and majestic, but that makes it look greater than it is. You don't expect this bird to have 0 power.

This artwork shows a little singing bird, which seems more accurate to reflect its fragile and meek nature.
45439: Birds of Paradise.text_posted:
__ART RANT__

In my humble opinion, this artwork in the new frame is the prettiest and most fitting printing of this card so far.

The only thing that slightly bugs me is the white border, but even that fits pretty nicely in this case.
And you can even get this in black-bordered perfection if you manage to get your hands on a foil version of these.

As CollectiveC said, the iridescent interpretation from Ravnica that's been used in the past ten years is imposing and majestic, but that makes it look greater than it is. You don't expect this bird to have 0 power.

This artwork shows a little singing bird, which seems more accurate to reflect its fragile and meek nature.

45445: Maro.author: Goatllama
45445: Maro.text_parsed: Various forms of what might be termed "collective consciousness" in modern societies have been identified by other sociologists, such as Mary Kelsey, going from solidarity attitudes and memes to extreme behaviors like group-think or herd behavior. Mary Kelsey, sociology lecturer in the University of California, Berkeley, used the term in the early 2000s to describe people within a social group, such as mothers, becoming aware of their shared traits and circumstances, and as a result acting as a community and achieving solidarity. Rather than existing as separate individuals, people come together as dynamic groups to share resources and knowledge. It has also developed as a way of describing how an entire community comes together to share similar values. This has also been termed "hive mind." From Wikipedia

45448: Thorn Elemental.author: Artscrafter
45448: Thorn Elemental.text_parsed:
This guy is a one-hit kill with Tainted Strike and any other power boost of 2 or more.

Turn 3 win is possible in mostly-standard casual if you go second. (I realize that pulling this off exactly is phenomenally unlikely, but still.)
T1: Forest, Joraga Treespeaker
T2: Swamp, give the Treespeaker a level, tap it for Lightning Greaves
T3: Land, Dark Ritual, Elvish Piper. Equip the greaves to the piper and trick this into play. Cast Giant Growth and Tainted Strike, equip the greaves, and swing for the win.

4.5 for this card? That seems a tad too high. It's a decent finisher, but... it feel like a 6 mana card for green. 7 doesn't break the bank, but even at 6 it's competing with truly epic creatures.

Compare to Thornling
-Much easier to cast.
-Protects itself.
-Trample (which is pseudo evasion)
-Can have haste
-Versatile

A big beater with psuedo evasion is nice, but I think by showing you Thornling you get what I mean. It could be more interesting, like Engulfing Slagwurm. They aren't necessarily better, but they sure seem a lot more worth it.

45448: Thorn Elemental.author: Deadling
45448: Thorn Elemental.text_parsed:
This was the card I first fell in love with! I have a couple of these, and almost bought a Japanese version, just cause! lol. I still run both of them in my aggro/mana ramp green deck. I even still run it's smaller versions, like a full set of Lone Wolf's, and maybe even a Pride of Lions or two. Attach a Blanchwood Armor to this guy, and even better!

Anyone who says this card isn't good anymore, hasn't been up against one, running right through their creatures. We may have a host of 10/10's and 15/15's now, but this is still a damn good creature. My friend almost always gave up when this hit the field if he had no way to take it down. Because he knew once it hit the field, the next turn it was going to have a Blanchwood Armor, or Exoskeletal Armor, or both, if not 2 Blanchwood's, lol.

Nostalgia and the fact I love this card, makes it a 5/5 for me.

45450: Plow Under.author: Guest1381794618
45450: Plow Under.text_parsed:
@Pedrodyl

4 Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary
4 Nature's Lore
4 Llanowar Elves
4 Sylvan Library
4 Woodfall Primus
4 Karn Liberated
4 Eternal Witness
4 Stampeding Serow
2 Primal Command
2Desert Twister
4 Plow Under

20 Forest.

Simple, easy. Ramp into nasty control and tempo with Rofellos, then set up Stampeding Serow with the Primus to blow crap up or Eternal Witness to Recur nasty crap like the command, twister, or plow under. If Rofellos is too exposed a route for you, cut the Sylvan Libraries and him and run a more traditional ramp, or just cut the Library and add a source of Shroud to your liking. Karn is there for additional Griefing and Control.

Turn Three Plow Under is absolutely devastating, and will generally cause people to scoop. In fact, this deck hardly ever wins games, it causes people to scoop out of frustration.
You will lose friends quickly playing this, especially those who fail to grasp the importance of critter kill.

45451: Fecundity.author: SIlverSkyz
45451: Fecundity.text_parsed:
Tokens DO activate battlefield to graveyard effects.

The thing is tokens get removed from the game as a state based action, so many people get it mistaken as not even hitting the graveyard. In reality a token should be moved to the graveyard, then immediately removed from the game; so an acceptable shortcut is to just remove them from the game. This action, however, confuses some people.

45454: Vernal Bloom.author: Ferlord
45454: Vernal Bloom.text_parsed:
It is a shame that only Forests, and not Green land sources (EG Gaea's Cradle) add an additional mana.

However, if you're playing mono-green EDH, what non-forest lands are you going to be playing?

Dryad Arbor?
Gaea's Cradle?
Pendelhaven?
Yavimaya Hollow?
Wirewood Lodge?
Oran-Rief, the Vastwood?
Tree of Tales?
Okina?
Mosswort Bridge?

I know I listed a whole bunch of them, but what other playable ones are you going to be playing? You only need so many, and with lots of cards like Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary and Arbor Elf, it's usually better to play more forests.

45461: Iron Star.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
45461: Iron Star.text_parsed:
Definitely agree with Sarroth. The flavour behind these little trinkets is kind of neat, but they are unfortunately bad. MaRo has cited this cycle (see also Wooden Sphere,Crystal Rod, Throne of Bone and Ivory Cup) as examples of cards that are supposed to teach newer players about overvaluing certain mechanics. Gaining life seems like it is never a bad thing, and adding a little zing to each spell you cast is appealing...

Still, though, if it means that you're waiting an extra turn to cast your things just so that you can gain 1 life, it slows your game badly while offering a comparatively poor reward. To realize this, you're really getting out of the spirit of the game and starting to think about its economy/mechanics... heady stuff for new players to realize on their own!
45461: Iron Star.text_posted:
Definitely agree with Sarroth.  The flavour behind these little trinkets is kind of neat, but they are unfortunately bad.  MaRo has cited this cycle (see also [autocard]Wooden Sphere[/autocard],[autocard]Crystal Rod[/autocard], [autocard]Throne of Bone[/autocard] and [autocard]Ivory Cup[/autocard]) as examples of cards that are supposed to teach newer players about overvaluing certain mechanics.  Gaining life seems like it is never a bad thing, and adding a little zing to each spell you cast is appealing... 

Still, though, if it means that you're waiting an extra turn to cast your things just so that you can gain 1 life, it slows your game badly while offering a comparatively poor reward.  To realize this, you're really getting out of the spirit of the game and starting to think about its economy/mechanics... heady stuff for new players to realize on their own!

45462: Wooden Sphere.author: Salient
45462: Wooden Sphere.text_parsed:
This is one of those cards that makes you grit your teeth when you see it reprinted, because 99% of new players misunderstand the mechanic and become disappointed or angry when you explain it to them.

"What do you mean I can't gain 6 life off my Llanowar Elves by tapping down all my forests? It never says you can do this only once per spell!!!" Redundant or no, I really wish they'd print "Activate this ability only once per spell" on it.

45462: Wooden Sphere.author: SirLibraryEater
45462: Wooden Sphere.text_parsed:
I think wizards is printing sucky cards like this on purpose, in order to teach new players what sucks and what doesn't.
They mean to make this card suck, just like they mean to make all the other 10 or so deceptively crappy cards in every set suck. Otherwise, new players would stumble upon great combos and the game wouldn't be as fun because it wouldn't require an understanding of the game. Just good cards.

45465: Patagia Golem.author: Ferlord
45465: Patagia Golem.text_parsed:
An absolutely awful card, one that probably didn't see play in its original printing.

I'm not so sure about limited, though. If it were printed now... Well, let's just say it'd be picked sooner than Rusted Sentinel would.

Also, you can argue that Dancing Scimitar and Primal Clay are better. Just the fact that you don't have to pay to give it flying is enough proof. The added toughness for Scimitar and the utility of Clay is pretty convincing as well (although, Scimitar is a little weaker).

STILL, a 1/5 with flying knows it's place: a great blocker. You don't know what to do with this.

I SUPPOSE you can also argue that Scimitar and Clay were rares, and this has always been uncommon, which makes my argument invalid. That's like comparing Craw Wurm to Vigor: They're in leagues of their own.

I can totally see myself playing this card in a casual deck with some wacky tribe. Frogs, Elephants, Slugs? No problem, this guy is cool!

Is it overcosted? Yes, and there are way better options for all of the competitive tribes (Soldiers, Vampires, Elves, Goblins, Zombies... name your pick), but on the other hand, he's a lord for all of those fun tribes that were never turned into something serious.

3.5/5 for being a fun casual card, although I think it should have retained its old rarity (uncommon) instead of being rare.

45472: Brass Herald.author: Sage_Phoenix
45472: Brass Herald.text_parsed: When I first started playing Magic, this card was the Holy Grail for my knight deck I made with other people's trash commons. Looking back on it, there's really not anything this guy is good for. Since Door of Destinies came out, it's not really that great in unusual tribal decks. Additionally, it's effect rarely draws you 4 cards. Especially not in an unusual tribal deck. However, the card is pretty decent with elves. You can cast him cheaply, and you can easily cast whatever elves you draw off of his ability. Elves also typically all elf cards, even the instants and sorceries have elf tribal attached to it so they're drawable. I haven't tried it yet, but I'm assuming that it will perform similarly in Goblins as well. If you're playing white, don't bother playing this. Just use Honor of the Pure for boosting, or Mentor of the Meek for card draw. Even Adaptive Automaton has replaced this card in many ways.
45472: Brass Herald.text_posted: When I first started playing Magic, this card was the Holy Grail for my knight deck I made with other people's trash commons.  Looking back on it, there's really not anything this guy is good for.  Since [autocard]Door of Destinies[/autocard] came out, it's not really that great in unusual tribal decks.  Additionally, it's effect rarely draws you 4 cards.  Especially not in an unusual tribal deck.  However, the card is pretty decent with elves.  You can cast him cheaply, and you can easily cast whatever elves you draw off of his ability.  Elves also typically all elf cards, even the instants and sorceries have elf tribal attached to it so they're drawable.  I haven't tried it yet, but I'm assuming that it will perform similarly in Goblins as well.  If you're playing white, don't bother playing this.  Just use [autocard]Honor of the Pure[/autocard] for boosting, or [autocard]Mentor of the Meek[/autocard] for card draw.  Even [autocard]Adaptive Automaton[/autocard] has replaced this card in many ways.

45477: Skull of Orm.author: longwinded
45477: Skull of Orm.text_parsed:
@tenkaze
Not true. Not everything is good in EDH. For example, everything that would be good in a normal constructed aggro deck is mediocre at best, and generally weak. Direct damage and point removal are okay, but not nearly as good as board sweepers. Between the larger life totals lengthening the game, the extra mana that a lengthy game allows, and the fact that 1-for-1 trades bare bad in multiplayer games, EDH winds up as a completely different beast.
45477: Skull of Orm.text_posted:
@tenkaze

45478: Ensnaring Bridge.author: Rhymes
45478: Ensnaring Bridge.text_parsed:
I used this card in combination with Goblin Warrens in a red goblin deck as a backup plan incase I don't get my Goblin King's out. I've gone countless matches getting 3-4 goblins each turn waiting until I have enough to kill my opponent.
My problems with this card is that I need to have 0 cards in hand in order to keep things stable, so if/when I draw a Goblin King I'll have to wait two turns in order to draw the cards required to attack, and with three of those killers in my deck my enemy might be able to kill me with flyers before I can attack.
To fix this problem I tossed a Shatter in there so I can attack quickly without waiting to build up cards.

Not perfect but then again it's only my backup plan.

4/5 - It's a double edged blade; be careful

45478: Ensnaring Bridge.author: dberry02
45478: Ensnaring Bridge.text_parsed:
This card is excellent with any deck that attacks with 0 power creatures.

For example, my Elf deck does this:
1. Have Ensnaring Bridge In play.
2. Attack my opponent with Taunting Elf (0 power)
3. Pump it with my Timberwatch Elf.
4. Repeat step 3 using any of the elf untap cards...

Also great to attack with Guiltfeeder, hehehe...

Or just attack with 1/1's on your turn, pump em with your spells, then play/ditch your card so your opponent's can't attack.

*Note* Just be prepared in case your opponent disenchants this. Nothing is worse than a "Suprise!" attack.

45478: Ensnaring Bridge.author: JaxsonBateman
45478: Ensnaring Bridge.text_parsed:
Why are people trying so hard to 'combo' this? Just play it in a deck where you can play out as much of your hand as you want, and can either refill it quickly enough to attack when you want, or uses a non-creature win condition.

For those that are looking to combo it though, keep in mind that triggers on attack declaration, like Exalted and Battle Cry, will resolve after the attacker/s have been declared. Meaning you can get through bigger guys than you'd usually be allowed.

45478: Ensnaring Bridge.author: blurrymadness
45478: Ensnaring Bridge.text_parsed:
Given the primary win con of most decks, if you can run this with small unblockables, you can get an easy win so long as you protect it. They can't attack, you attack each turn with guys they can't do anything to (Nether traitor is a prime example.) Simply play your spell or land every turn in your second phase.

Combine with Signal Pest for colorless evasive pumping or the best of all, Inkfathom Witch. With Tormented Soul these pumpers can quickly end opponents, and you're in Blue and Black, the best draw spells of magic and the easiest colors to discard in and the easiest colors to get evasive/unblockable creatures in.

Apostle's Blessing can protect your Bridge colorlessly; and can protect your creatures in a pinch (mostly the witch.)

Given the theme, consider Thief of Hope for occasional life-gain, bleed, and recursion of your Tormented Souls.

45478: Ensnaring Bridge.author: Ferlord
45478: Ensnaring Bridge.text_parsed:
A great EDH general who can abuse this is Malfegor, oddly enough.

One thing you're going to have to understand is that you'll almost never have a full hand with Malfegor, considering his effect. The one problem discarding your whole hand provides is you now have fewer ways to solve problems: any of them are in your grave now. But if you have this out, you're now invulnerable to being attacked.

All in all, it's a great artifact that can halt a games speed drastically, kind of like Propaganda and/or Ghostly Prison. Just remember that it affects all players, including yourself.

45478: Ensnaring Bridge.text_parsed:
Awesome card for protection, especially against fatties of all kinds. It fits perfectly in any weeny deck, where most creatures rather rely on comboing with each other, than on mere power.

I run this in a faerie tribal deck and it´s perfect to win some time to be able to build up your win condition. Creatures like Sprite Noble, for example, or anything else which lets you pump your creatures during your attack, also fit perfectly to this card, since it makes you be more flexible to still be able to attack yourself, while the bridge is in play. Oona's Prowler also fits perfectly to this, since it gives you more control over your hand size. Or also the Quietus Spike is very nice to use with it.

I just wished that they would reprint this card, because the art isn't really what I would could beautiful...

45480: Dingus Egg.author: Enelysios
45480: Dingus Egg.text_parsed:
Banning this was a mistake, this card isn't very good.

Why is this so highly rated? I mean, not that it is too awful, it is something with Armageddon, but it does not deserve a place in dedicated land destruction. (At the time it was banned, it wasn't even played in high end LD decks) The win condition is the least important part of a land destruction deck. Anything can be a wincon because the whole point of your deck is that you prevent the opponent from acting. Sinkhole needed banning, not Dingus Egg.

Dingus Egg is relatively expensive, slow (Two a turn most likely, until your opponent runs out of land drops) and does nothing for you besides damage your opponent. So don't waste slots in your deck on it! Run cards that can effect the board or kill your opponent. Burn spells like Lightning Bolt, a creature (Preferably with an ability like Dark Confidant) or now you can even use a planeswalker. All of these can have utility in your deck outside of just whittling your opponent down, and all of these are probably faster than Dingus Egg.

45484: Urza's Armor.author: Krysto
45484: Urza's Armor.text_parsed:
Stupid combo time!
With Urza's Armor, set up the following:
Stuffy Doll, targeting yourself.
Outrider en-Kor, with Pariah attached.

All damage dealt to you is dealt to the Outrider, which sends the damage, one point at a time to the doll, which sends the damage, one point at a time, to you, preventing all of it.
Of course, you could just Pariah the Stuffy Doll and target your opponent, but where's the fun in that?

45486: Planar Portal.author: JaxsonBateman

Synergy like that is awesome in EDH - and this card has synergy written all over it.

45487: Aladdin's Ring.author: MaestroWingnut
45487: Aladdin's Ring.text_parsed:
Nervan must not have been referring to this ring.

To be honest, I would love this card if it dealt 1 damage instead and lost the tap payment, because although that would make this card even worse, it would make this card more understandable. Making it deal 4 damage makes it seem that the Ring was meant to be good and rewarding to the player that got enough mana. For this effect of "your chronically built-up mana finally paying off" to be fulfilled with the cost of 8 colorless and tapping I think the damage would need to be at least 5. Having the damage at 4 is confusing in this way, since the idea of it wants play but the numbers create too insufficient an effect for the player, leaving them disappointed. Having the damge at 1 would shatter the illusion that the card is supposed to be a nuclear bomb that ends the game, as well as admit to not having play ability instead of trying to achieve so, and thus makes the card more understandable. Losing the tap payment would make this useful in infinite mana combos as well.

For this effect of "your chronically built-up mana finally paying off" to be fulfilled with the cost of 8 colorless and tapping I think the damage would need to be at least 5. 45491: Coastal Tower.author: DarthParallax
45491: Coastal Tower.text_parsed:
Refuge Cycle and this Cycle have now been ousted by the Gate Cycle in Return to Ravnica:

Golgari Guildgate
Azorius Guildgate
Rakdos Guildgate
Selesnya Guildgate
Izzet Guildgate

1. These are 'budget' lands- there are better lands, so if you're looking at these, you want cheap cards.
Common is better than Uncommon for getting Cheap cards. Actually have a great chance of picking up a full 40 set for less than $5. $6 at the absolute most, if someone really charges you 15c each, but that's kind of jerky. Commons should be: 'you can have a huge pile of them, plus 10 crap rares at a dollar a rare'.

2. They have a relevant subtype- 'Gate'- that can make some other cards a lot better/reasonable. I don't think this new 'Gate' thing will be hugely important outside of Limited, even considering the name of the set 'Gatecrash', but it does mean that budget decks with budget synergies will be buildable, and this neither this cycle nor the Refuges have enough synergies to really point you one direction or another.

3. I think the Ravnica Gate lands are going to take the spot of the Alara Shard Lands as 'what budget players use to play Gold Decks' and Gate decks might even turn out to be the Best non-rare manafixers ever.

45494: Shivan Oasis.author: DacenOctavio
45494: Shivan Oasis.text_parsed:
It won't directly hurt you like Karplusan Forest, and it may be strictly worse than Rootbound Crag, but it works and doesn't have a long-term drawback unlike the former.

All three of those styles of dual lands evoke different play styles; you won't find a tournament player playing with these, as they prefer untapped speed; Karplusan Forest and City of Brass give unconditional untapped speed at a price.

Rootbound Crag and friends operate under the assumption you run a few basic lands, otherwise they're exactly like the 8th Edition cycle of nonbasics.

Copperline Gorge & Co. operate under an opposite philosophy to the above in that early game speed is the most important, and playing these as your first 3 lands will put you the farthest ahead. However, drawing them mid-to-late game means they come into play tapped, which is only a drawback if your deck really needs that mana at that point in the game.

46438: Plains.author: marmaris74
46438: Plains.text_parsed:
If anything, Mox Pearl is worse than plains.

1: The "four-card" limit. Plains just straight-up ignores it.
2: Plains doesn't die to artifact removal. Play only Moxen and a Shattering Spree will be lethal to you.
3: Landfall. 'Nough said.
4: Those moonfolk with their returning land abilities. Okay, so no one played those.
5: Creatures that need to sac lands, e.g scythe tiger or akki avalanchers.
6: The art on Mox Pearl is kinda boring, some plains have really cool art.

I think that's reason enough for why plains kicks ass.
